source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath

prev_sentence: GAFFER.

question: The birds looked upon me as nothing but a man, [MASK] a trifling creature without wings--and they would have nothing to do with me.
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: No devil of a doctor can stop them for a moment.
next_sentence: Were it not so I would build a small cabin for myself among their crowd of nests and pass my days counting the sea waves.

question: Women from our dairy village do come and [MASK] their water from the river; but then it isn't everyone who has a red saree to put on.
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: Good, that's right.
next_sentence: But, my dear child, surely you must have been there for a walk some time.

question: No, you don't; you squat there and make friends with the whole lot of people [MASK] here, old and young, as if they are holding a fair right under my eaves--flesh and blood won't stand that strain.
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: MADHAV.
next_sentence: Just see--your face is quite pale.

question: Surely, if your name's on the letter they will [MASK] you out.

prev_sentence: BOYS.
next_sentence: AMAL.

question: Indeed, they live among the green hills; and in the time of the sunset when there is a red glow on the hillside, all the birds with their green wings [MASK] back to their nests.
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: GAFFER.
next_sentence: AMAL.

question: There is only one way to save him and that is to keep him out of this autumn wind and [MASK].

title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: The doctor says all the organs of his little body are at loggerheads with each other, and there isn't much hope for his life.
next_sentence: But you are such a terror!

source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath

prev_sentence: GAFFER.

question: This little child does have an instinct of [MASK].

question: Say, but you're off to sleep [MASK].

question: No one can ever [MASK] me away.
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: But the doctor won't let me go out.
next_sentence: I've got to stay here all day long.

question: Right down the road there; see that [MASK] palm-leaf umbrella hopping along?
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: WATCHMAN.
next_sentence: That's him!

question: All of us have to get there one [MASK], my child.

title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: WATCHMAN.
next_sentence: AMAL.

question: He'd made a little pile; and so kings and padishahs are everyday [MASK] with his people.
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: Madhav is devilish swell nowadays.
next_sentence: Let me find him once and I'll make him dance.

question: Don't [MASK] me stay at home all day! ''
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: I shall say, "Make me your postman, that I may go about lantern in hand, delivering your letters from door to door.

question: You won't need to ask, my [MASK], he'll give it to you of his own accord.
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: GAFFER.
next_sentence: AMAL.

question: No, they don't have [MASK] for that sort of nonsense.
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: But I suppose the learned people--  MADHAV.
next_sentence: They are not crazy like you.

question: He may [MASK] if he is a friend of yours.
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: Very well, my child.
next_sentence: MADHAV [Whispering into AMAL'S ear] My child, the King loves you.

question: What with this [MASK] of yours at your age, too, to get children out of doors!
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: But you are such a terror!

question: Then he took out from his bundle some gram-flour, [MASK] it with water and began to eat.
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: And when he got to where the water flows under the fig tree, he stopped and washed his feet in the stream.
next_sentence: Then he tied up his bundle and shouldered it again; tucked up his cloth above his knees and crossed the stream.

question: You'll bring me to [MASK] if you do.
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: Why take the King's name in vain?
next_sentence: AMAL.

source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: No one will scold me.
next_sentence: I'll get you new ones when these are old.

question: Else, what was the use in heaping up so many large stones to make such a big [MASK] of it, eh!
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: Now listen, since that hill stands there upright as a barrier, it means you can't get beyond it.
next_sentence: AMAL.

question: The doctor can't know and he reads such huge [MASK]!
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: What a thing to say!
next_sentence: AMAL.

question: But now that he has come, goodness knows from where, my heart is [MASK] with his dear self, and my home will be no home to me when he leaves.
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: Before he came, nothing mattered; I felt so free.
next_sentence: Doctor, do you think he--  PHYSICIAN.

question: The doctor [MASK] all the organs of his little body are at loggerheads with each other, and there isn't much hope for his life.
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: MADHAV.
next_sentence: There is only one way to save him and that is to keep him out of this autumn wind and sun.

source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: You're the King's chum.
next_sentence: Ha, ha, ha!

question: Who is yelling after me on the [MASK]?
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: HEADMAN.
next_sentence: Oh, you wretched monkey!

question: Open wide all the [MASK] and windows.
source_info: The Post Office by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Post Office
prev_sentence: How close it is here!
next_sentence: [Feeling AMAL'S body] How do you feel, my child?

question: The divine in her heart is suffering from the injuries inflicted by her hands upon the world ,--and from this [MASK] of her higher nature flows the secret balm which will bring healing to those injuries.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: The West could never have risen to the eminence she has reached, if her strength were merely the strength of the brute, or of the machine.
next_sentence: Time after time she has fought against herself and has undone the chains, which with her own hands she had fastened round helpless limbs; and though she forced poison down the throat of a great nation at the point of sword for gain of money, she herself woke up to withdraw from it, to wash her hands clean again.

question: And it has come to pass, that the children of those heroes, who would keep their word at the point of death, who would disdain to cheat men for vulgar profit, who even in their fight would much rather court defeat than be dishonourable, have become energetic in [MASK] with falsehoods and do not feel humiliated by gaining advantage from them.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: It is so easy to dull our sense of honour and delicacy of mind with constant abrasion, while falsehoods stalk abroad with proud steps in the name of trade, politics and patriotism, that any protest against their perpetual intrusion into our lives is considered to be sentimentalism, unworthy of true manliness.
next_sentence: And this has been effected by the charm of the word 'modern.'

question: There, display and [MASK], in dress, in furniture, in costly entertainments, are startling.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: In other great countries, signs of man's power loomed large, and I saw vast organisations which showed efficiency in all their features.
next_sentence: They seem to push you back into a corner, like a poor intruder at a feast; they are apt to make you envious, or take your breath away with amazement.

question: Because it has no roots in sentiments, it is so dangerously [MASK] to handle.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: In political civilisation, the state is an abstraction and relationship of men utilitarian.
next_sentence: Half a century has been enough for you to master this machine; and there are men among you, whose fondness for it exceeds their love for the living ideals which were born with the birth of your nation and nursed in your centuries.

question: There are others, who [MASK] that they see something contrary.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: My answer is, because I see something which is positive.
next_sentence: It only shows, that I am looking on the picture side of the canvas, and they on the blank side.

question: This developed their [MASK] loyalty, their single-minded devotion to the obligations of honour, their power of complete self-surrender and fearless acceptance of death and danger.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: The people themselves, being free from the responsibilities of the baser and more heinous side of those adventures, had all the advantage of the heroic and the human disciplines derived from them.
next_sentence: Therefore the ideals, whose seats were in the hearts of the people, would not undergo any serious change owing to the policies adopted by the kings or generals.

question: And this has been effected by the [MASK] of the word 'modern . '
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: And it has come to pass, that the children of those heroes, who would keep their word at the point of death, who would disdain to cheat men for vulgar profit, who even in their fight would much rather court defeat than be dishonourable, have become energetic in dealing with falsehoods and do not feel humiliated by gaining advantage from them.
next_sentence: But if undiluted utility be modern, beauty is of all ages; if mean selfishness be modern, the human ideals are no new inventions.

question: We must try to come to that normal state of mind, by which we can clearly discern our own danger and avoid it, without being unjust towards the source of that [MASK].
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: The reaction of disillusionment is just as unreal as the first shock of illusion.
next_sentence: There is always the natural temptation in us of wishing to pay back Europe in her own coin, and return contempt for contempt and evil for evil.

question: But this should never be allowed to go beyond her [MASK] of self-preservation.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: I do not for a moment suggest, that Japan should be unmindful of acquiring modern weapons of self-protection.
next_sentence: She must know that the real power is not in the weapons themselves, but in the man who wields those weapons; and when he, in his eagerness for power, multiplies his weapons at the cost of his own soul, then it is he who is in even greater danger than his enemies.

question: We know that, in the early stage of man's moral immaturity, he only feels [MASK] for the god whose malevolence he dreads.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: They admit Japan's equality with themselves, only when they know that Japan also possesses the key to open the floodgate of hell-fire upon the fair earth, whenever she chooses, and can dance, in their own measure, the devil dance of pillage, murder, and ravishment of innocent women, while the world goes to ruin.
next_sentence: But is this the ideal of man which we can look up to with pride?

question: Time after time she has [MASK] against herself and has undone the chains, which with her own hands she had fastened round helpless limbs; and though she forced poison down the throat of a great nation at the point of sword for gain of money, she herself woke up to withdraw from it, to wash her hands clean again.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: The divine in her heart is suffering from the injuries inflicted by her hands upon the world,--and from this pain of her higher nature flows the secret balm which will bring healing to those injuries.
next_sentence: This shows hidden springs of humanity in spots which look dead and barren.

question: All particular civilisation is the interpretation of particular [MASK] experience.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: For the rhythm of beauty is the inner spirit, whose outer body is organisation.
next_sentence: Europe seems to have felt emphatically the conflict of things in the universe, which can only be brought under control by conquest.

question: Collisions are certain to occur; for it has to [MASK] upon organised lines, it is too heavy to choose its own course freely; and once it is off the rails, its endless train of vehicles is dislocated.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: Therefore I ask you to have the strength of faith and clarity of mind to know for certain, that the lumbering structure of modern progress, riveted by the iron bolts of efficiency, which runs upon the wheels of ambition, cannot hold together for long.
next_sentence: A day will come, when it will fall in a heap of ruin and cause serious obstruction to the traffic of the world.

question: But is this the [MASK] of man which we can look up to with pride?
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: We know that, in the early stage of man's moral immaturity, he only feels reverence for the god whose malevolence he dreads.
next_sentence: After centuries of civilisation nations fearing each other like the prowling wild beasts of the night time; shutting their doors of hospitality; combining only for purpose of aggression or defence; hiding in their holes their trade secrets, state secrets, secrets of their armaments; making peace offerings to the barking dogs of each other with the meat which does not belong to them; holding down fallen races struggling to stand upon their feet; counting their safety only upon the feebleness of the rest of humanity; with their right hands dispensing religion to weaker peoples, while robbing them with their left,--is there anything in this to make us envious?

question: But these costly rituals for invocation of the evil spirit lead through a path of [MASK] to the brink of cataclysm.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: All her armaments and diplomacy are directed upon this one object.
next_sentence: The furies of terror, which the West has let loose upon God's world, come back to threaten herself and goad her into preparations of more and more frightfulness; this gives her no rest and makes her forget all else but the perils that she causes to others, and incurs herself.

question: We shall try them and build sheds for them, but not [MASK] them in our homes, or temples.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: We are willing to buy their machine-made systems, not with our hearts, but with our brains.
next_sentence: There are races, who worship the animals they kill; we can buy meat from them, when we are hungry, but not the worship which goes with the killing.

question: She must know that the real power is not in the weapons themselves, but in the man who wields those weapons; and when he, in his eagerness for power, multiplies his weapons at the cost of his own soul, then it is he who is in even greater [MASK] than his enemies.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: But this should never be allowed to go beyond her instinct of self-preservation.
next_sentence: Things that are living are so easily hurt; therefore they require protection.

question: She feeds upon their dead flesh and [MASK] fat upon it, so long as the carcasses remain fresh ,--but they are sure to rot at last, and the dead will take their revenge, by spreading pollution far and wide and poisoning the vitality of the feeder.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: To the worship of this devil of politics she sacrifices other countries as victims.
next_sentence: Japan had all her wealth of humanity, her harmony of heroism and beauty, her depth of self-control and richness of self-expression; yet the Western nations felt no respect for her, till she proved that the bloodhounds of Satan are not only bred in the kennels of Europe, but can also be domesticated in Japan and fed with man's miseries.

question: Those who have no [MASK] for music, hear sounds, but not the song.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: Those who have not this vision, merely see events and facts, and not their inner association.
next_sentence: Therefore when, by the mere reason of the lengthiness of their suffering, they threaten to establish the fact of the tune to be a noise, one need not be anxious about music.

question: They seem to push you back into a corner, like a poor intruder at a feast; they are apt to [MASK] you envious, or take your breath away with amazement.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: There, display and extravagance, in dress, in furniture, in costly entertainments, are startling.
next_sentence: There, you do not feel man as supreme; you are hurled against the stupendousness of things that alienates.

question: In past ages we had foreign invasions, there had been cruelty and bloodshed, intrigues of jealousy and avarice, but they never touched the soul of the people deeply; for the [MASK], as a body, never participated in these games.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: And nations, who sedulously cultivate moral blindness as the cult of patriotism, will end their existence in a sudden and violent death.
next_sentence: They were merely the outcome of individual ambitions.

question: It is science, but not its wrong application in life ,--a mere imitation of our science teachers who reduce it into a superstition absurdly invoking its aid for all [MASK] purposes.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: It is independence of thought and action, not tutelage under European schoolmasters.
next_sentence: Science, when it oversteps its limits and occupies the whole region of life, has its fascination.

question: What has impressed me most in this country is the conviction that you have realised nature's secrets, not by methods of analytical knowledge, but by [MASK].
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: You see a people, whose heart has come out and scattered itself in profusion in its commonest utensils of everyday life in its social institutions, in its manners, that are carefully perfect, and in its dealings with things that are not only deft, but graceful in every movement.
next_sentence: You have known her language of lines and music of colours, the symmetry in her irregularities, and the cadence in her freedom of movements; you have seen how she leads her immense crowds of things yet avoids all frictions; how the very conflicts in her creations break out in dance and music; how her exuberance has the aspect of the fullness of self-abandonment, and not a mere dissipation of display.

question: She does not [MASK] of her mastery of nature, but to her she brings, with infinite care and joy, her offerings of love.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: But Japan has felt, in her world, the touch of some presence, which has evoked in her soul a feeling of reverent adoration.
next_sentence: Her relationship with the world is the deeper relationship of heart.

question: For man's struggle for existence is to exist in the fullness of his nature ,--not by curtailing all that is best in him and dwarfing his existence itself, but by [MASK] all the responsibilities of his spiritual life, even through death and defeat.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: But even science cannot tow humanity against truth and be successful; and those whose minds are crude enough to plan their lives upon the supposition, that man is merely a hunter and his paradise the paradise of sportsman, will be rudely awakened in the midst of their trophies of skeletons and skulls.
next_sentence: I do not for a moment suggest, that Japan should be unmindful of acquiring modern weapons of self-protection.

question: Life based upon [MASK] is attractive to some men, because it has all the characteristics of sport; it feigns seriousness, but is not profound.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: Man truly exists in the ideal of perfection, whose depth and height are not yet measured.
next_sentence: When you go a-hunting, the less pity you have the better; for your one object is to chase the game and kill it, to feel that you are the greater animal, that your method of destruction is thorough and scientific.

question: It is easy to be unfair in one's judgment when one is faced with human miseries ,--and pessimism is the result of building theories while the mind is [MASK].
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: When we truly know the Europe which is great and good, we can effectively save ourselves from the Europe which is mean and grasping.
next_sentence: To despair of humanity is only possible, if we lose faith in the power which brings to it strength, when its defeat is greatest, and calls out new life from the depth of its destruction.

question: There, you do not feel man as supreme; you are [MASK] against the stupendousness of things that alienates.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: They seem to push you back into a corner, like a poor intruder at a feast; they are apt to make you envious, or take your breath away with amazement.
next_sentence: But, in Japan, it is not the display of power, or wealth, that is the predominating element.

question: But our fear is, that the poison may be more powerful than the food, and what is strength in her to-day may not be the sign of health, but the contrary; for it may be temporarily caused by the [MASK] of the balance of life.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: There is one safety for us upon which we hope we may count, and that is, that we can claim Europe herself, as our ally, in our resistance to her temptations and to her violent encroachments; for she has ever carried her own standard of perfection, by which we can measure her falls and gauge her degrees of failure, by which we can call her before her own tribunal and put her to shame,--the shame which is the sign of the true pride of nobleness.
next_sentence: Our fear is that evil has a fateful fascination, when it assumes dimensions which are colossal,--and though at last, it is sure to lose its centre of gravity, by its abnormal disproportion, the mischief which it creates before its fall may be beyond reparation.

question: And we must know for certain, that however modern may be the proficiency, which clips and cripples man for the sake of [MASK] and machines, it will never live to be old.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: But if undiluted utility be modern, beauty is of all ages; if mean selfishness be modern, the human ideals are no new inventions.
next_sentence: When Japan is in imminent peril of neglecting to realise where she is great, it is the duty of a foreigner like myself to remind her, that she has given rise to a civilisation which is perfect in its form, and has evolved a sense of sight which clearly sees truth in beauty and beauty in truth.

question: This shows hidden springs of humanity in [MASK] which look dead and barren.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: Time after time she has fought against herself and has undone the chains, which with her own hands she had fastened round helpless limbs; and though she forced poison down the throat of a great nation at the point of sword for gain of money, she herself woke up to withdraw from it, to wash her hands clean again.
next_sentence: It proves that the deeper truth in her nature, which can survive such career of cruel cowardliness, is not greed, but reverence for unselfish ideals.

question: But the tidal wave of [MASK] has swept over your land from that part of the world, where business is business, and honesty is followed in it merely as the best policy.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: You had your own industry in Japan; how scrupulously honest and true it was, you can see by its products,--by their grace and strength, their conscientiousness in details, where they can hardly be observed.

title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: Japan must be reminded, that it is her sense of the rhythm of life and of all things, her genius for simplicity, her love for cleanliness, her definiteness of thought and action, her cheerful fortitude, her immense reserve of force in self-control, her sensitiveness to her code of honour and defiance of death, which have given her the power to resist the cyclonic storm of exploitation that has sprung from the shores of Europe circling round and round the world.
next_sentence: Such a civilisation has the gift of immortality; for it does not offend against the laws of creation and is not assailed by all the forces of nature.

question: It is so easy to dull our sense of honour and delicacy of mind with constant abrasion, while falsehoods stalk abroad with proud steps in the name of trade, politics and patriotism, that any [MASK] against their perpetual intrusion into our lives is considered to be sentimentalism, unworthy of true manliness.

title: The Spirit of Japan

title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: Does not the voice come to us, through the din of war, the shrieks of hatred, the wailings of despair, through the churning up of the unspeakable filth which has been accumulating for ages in the bottom of this civilisation,--the voice which cries to our soul, that the tower of national selfishness, which goes by the name of patriotism, which has raised its banner of treason against heaven, must totter and fall with a crash, weighed down by its own bulk, its flag kissing the dust, its light extinguished?
next_sentence: For when this conflagration consumes itself and dies down, leaving its memorial in ashes, the eternal light will again shine in the East,--the East which has been the birth-place of the morning sun of man's history.

question: It pursues success with [MASK] and thoroughness, and takes no account of the higher nature of man.

prev_sentence: It only shows, that I am looking on the picture side of the canvas, and they on the blank side.
