question: Do we not [MASK] signs of this even now?
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: A day will come, when it will fall in a heap of ruin and cause serious obstruction to the traffic of the world.
next_sentence: Does not the voice come to us, through the din of war, the shrieks of hatred, the wailings of despair, through the churning up of the unspeakable filth which has been accumulating for ages in the bottom of this civilisation,--the voice which cries to our soul, that the tower of national selfishness, which goes by the name of patriotism, which has raised its banner of treason against heaven, must totter and fall with a crash, weighed down by its own bulk, its flag kissing the dust, its light extinguished?

question: What is merely modern ,--as [MASK] and methods of organisation ,--can be transplanted; but what is vitally human has fibres so delicate, and roots so numerous and far reaching, that it dies when moved from its soil.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: Likewise the culture, which has so kindly adapted itself to your soil,--so intimate with life, so human,--not only needed tilling and weeding in past ages, but still needs anxious work and watching.
next_sentence: Therefore I am afraid of the rude pressure of the political ideals of the West upon your own.

question: Half a century has been enough for you to master this machine; and there are [MASK] among you, whose fondness for it exceeds their love for the living ideals which were born with the birth of your nation and nursed in your centuries.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: Because it has no roots in sentiments, it is so dangerously easy to handle.
next_sentence: It is like a child, who, in the excitement of his play, imagines he likes his playthings better than his mother.

question: One must bear in [MASK], that those who have the true modern spirit need not modernise, just as those who are truly brave are not braggarts.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: It is nothing but mimicry, only affectation is louder than the original, and it is too literal.
next_sentence: Modernism is not in the dress of the Europeans; or in the hideous structures, where their children are interned when they take their lessons; or in the square houses with flat straight wall-surfaces, pierced with parallel lines of windows, where these people are caged in their lifetime; certainly modernism is not in their ladies' bonnets, carrying on them loads of incongruities.

question: We must know that man's business has to be more than mere business, and so have to be his [MASK] and politics.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: We must not vitiate our children's minds with the superstition, that business is business, war is war, politics is politics.
next_sentence: You had your own industry in Japan; how scrupulously honest and true it was, you can see by its products,--by their grace and strength, their conscientiousness in details, where they can hardly be observed.

question: It is like a [MASK], who, in the excitement of his play, imagines he likes his playthings better than his mother.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: Half a century has been enough for you to master this machine; and there are men among you, whose fondness for it exceeds their love for the living ideals which were born with the birth of your nation and nursed in your centuries.
next_sentence: Where man is at his greatest, he is unconscious.

question: Have you never felt shame, when you see the trade advertisements, not only [MASK] the whole town with lies and exaggerations, but invading the green fields, where the peasants do their honest labour, and the hill-tops, which greet the first pure light of the morning?
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: But the tidal wave of falsehood has swept over your land from that part of the world, where business is business, and honesty is followed in it merely as the best policy.
next_sentence: It is so easy to dull our sense of honour and delicacy of mind with constant abrasion, while falsehoods stalk abroad with proud steps in the name of trade, politics and patriotism, that any protest against their perpetual intrusion into our lives is considered to be sentimentalism, unworthy of true manliness.

question: And the true expression of this love is in the language of beauty, which is so [MASK] universal in this land.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: The ideal of "maitri" is at the bottom of your culture,--"maitri" with men and "maitri" with Nature.
next_sentence: This is the reason why a stranger, like myself, instead of feeling envy or humiliation before these manifestations of beauty, these creations of love, feels a readiness to participate in the joy and glory of such revealment of the human heart.

question: Your instincts have become true, your senses [MASK], and your hands have acquired natural skill.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: But here, in Japan, it seems to have achieved its success, and deeply sunk into the minds of all men, and permeated their muscles and nerves.
next_sentence: The genius of Europe has given her people the power of organisation, which has specially made itself manifest in politics and commerce and in coordinating scientific knowledge.

question: They were merely the [MASK] of individual ambitions.
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: In past ages we had foreign invasions, there had been cruelty and bloodshed, intrigues of jealousy and avarice, but they never touched the soul of the people deeply; for the people, as a body, never participated in these games.
next_sentence: The people themselves, being free from the responsibilities of the baser and more heinous side of those adventures, had all the advantage of the heroic and the human disciplines derived from them.

question: And the life of science is that superficial [MASK].
source_info: The Spirit of Japan by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: The Spirit of Japan
prev_sentence: Because, therefore, a sportsman is only a superficial man,--his fullness of humanity not being there to hamper him,--he is successful in killing innocent life and is happy.
next_sentence: It pursues success with skill and thoroughness, and takes no account of the higher nature of man.

question: There the reign of [MASK] ceases, and there our function is not to get but to be.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: But that side of our existence whose direction is towards the infinite seeks not wealth, but freedom and joy.
next_sentence: To be what?

question: Such a life, it may be [MASK], tends to have the effect of dulling human intelligence and dwarfing the incentives to progress by lowering the standards of existence.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: It was surrounded by the vast life of nature, was fed and clothed by her, and had the closest and most constant intercourse with her varying aspects.
next_sentence: But in ancient India we find that the circumstances of forest life did not overcome man's mind, and did not enfeeble the current of his energies, but only gave to it a particular direction.

question: The day comes to us every morning, naked and white, [MASK] as a flower.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: The play of life and death we see everywhere--this transmutation of the old into the new.
next_sentence: But we know it is old.

question: Still, so long as the strength of the current is not lost, there is no fear; the obstructions and the [MASK] accumulations of his activity are dissipated and carried away; the impetus corrects its own mistakes.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Sometimes he wanders so far that his work tends to lose its meaning, and his rushings to and fro create fearful eddies round different centres--eddies of self-interest, of pride of power.
next_sentence: Only when the soul sleeps in stagnation do its enemies gain overmastering strength, and these obstructions become too clogging to be fought through.

question: In his to be he is infinite, there is his heaven, his [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: In what he is he is small, and if we could conceive him stopping there for eternity we should have an idea of the most awful hell that man can imagine.
next_sentence: His is is occupied every moment with what it can get and have done with; his to be is hungering for something which is more than can be got, which he never can lose because he never has possessed.

question: The same [MASK] that is the embodiment of endless activity without is the perfect expression of beauty and peace within.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: But when this same flower enters the heart of men its aspect of busy practicality is gone, and it becomes the very emblem of leisure and repose.
next_sentence: Science here warns us that we are mistaken, that the purpose of a flower is nothing but what is outwardly manifested, and that the relation of beauty and sweetness which we think it bears to us is all our own making, gratuitous and imaginary.

question: [MASK] us consider this point more fully.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: When Buddha mentioned upon the way of realising mankind from the grip of misery he came to this truth: that when man attains his highest end by merging the individual in the universal, he becomes free from the thraldom of pain.
next_sentence: A student of mine once related to me his adventure in a storm, and complained that all the time he was troubled with the feeling that this great commotion in nature behaved to him as if he were no more than a mere handful of dust.

question: This [MASK] sureness of reality sometimes crosses our will, and very often leads us to disaster, just as the firmness of the earth invariably hurts the falling child who is learning to walk.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: So, if it is a truth that the yearning of our nature is for reality, and that our personality cannot be happy with a fantastic universe of its own creation, then it is clearly best for it that our will can only deal with things by following their law, and cannot do with them just as it pleases.
next_sentence: Nevertheless it is the same firmness that hurts him which makes his walking possible.

question: When we try to make this appearance independent of [MASK], then our attempt brings misery and proves its own futility in the end.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: So in the freedom of our will, we have the same dualism of appearance and truth--our self-will is only the appearance of freedom and love is the truth.
next_sentence: Everything has this dualism of mÄyÄ and satyam, appearance and truth.

question: At one place it comes as a slave, and at another as a [MASK] thing.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Beauty becomes its only qualification.
next_sentence: How, then, should we give credit to its first recommendation and disbelieve the second one?

question: It is most [MASK] because it is not universal.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: We are absolutely bankrupt if we are deprived of this specialty, this individuality, which is the only thing we can call our own; and which, if lost, is also a loss to the whole world.
next_sentence: And therefore only through it can we gain the universe more truly than if we were lying within its breast unconscious of our distinctiveness.

question: When this home of mine is made thine, that very moment is it taken across, even while its old [MASK] enclose it.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Till then it will struggle on, and its heart will ever cry, "Ferryman, lead me across."
next_sentence: This "I" is restless.

question: It is self deception on a large [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Thus our lust, our greed, our love of comfort result in cheapening man to his lowest value.
next_sentence: Our desires blind us to the truth that there is in man, and this is the greatest wrong done by ourselves to our own soul.

question: Have we been able to [MASK] it in our heart where we keep enshrined things that are of deathless value to us?
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: The question is, In what manner do we accept this world, which is a perfect gift of joy?
next_sentence: We are frantically busy making use of the forces of the universe to gain more and more power; we feed and we clothe ourselves from its stores, we scramble for its riches, and it becomes for us a field of fierce competition.

question: It is the principle of our physical [MASK], it links our life with its past and its future and maintains the unity of its parts.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: It has no concern with the fulfilment of our immediate bodily desires, but it goes beyond the present time.
next_sentence: He who is wise knows it, and makes his other physical wishes harmonise with it.

question: We are [MASK] in his consciousness body and soul.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: To feel all, to be conscious of everything, is his spirit.
next_sentence: It is through his consciousness that the sun attracts the earth; it is through his consciousness that the light-waves are being transmitted from planet to planet.

question: The progress of our [MASK] is like a perfect poem.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: But if the poem goes on interminably, never expressing the idea of the whole, only throwing off disconnected images, however beautiful, it becomes wearisome and unprofitable in the extreme.
next_sentence: It has an infinite idea which once realised makes all movements full of meaning and joy.

question: It is like looking at a piece of cloth through a [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: We lose sight of the wholeness of a life of which death is part.
next_sentence: It appears like a net; we gaze at the big holes and shiver in imagination.

question: The play of life and death we see everywhere--this transmutation of the old into the [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: It must follow the eternal rhythm and touch the fundamental unity at every step, and thus maintain its separation balanced in beauty and strength.
next_sentence: The day comes to us every morning, naked and white, fresh as a flower.

question: In reconcilement of this contradiction in us we come to the truth that in the [MASK] of death and life there is a harmony.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: This it is in us which makes us sceptical of death, even when the fact of death cannot be doubted.
next_sentence: We know that the life of a soul, which is finite in its expression and infinite in its principle, must go through the portals of death in its journey to realise the infinite.

question: It is the one living truth that [MASK] all realities true.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: His object of worship is present everywhere.
next_sentence: This truth is not only of knowledge but of devotion.

question: When we look at the world through the veil of our desires we make it small and [MASK], and fail to perceive its full truth.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: As with man, so with this universe.
next_sentence: Of course it is obvious that the world serves us and fulfils our needs, but our relation to it does not end there.

question: For only in [MASK] are we alone.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: At every step we have to take into account others than ourselves.
next_sentence: A poet is a true poet when he can make his personal idea joyful to all men, which he could not do if he had not a medium common to all his audience.

question: He is all-conscious in [MASK], or the world of extension; and he is all-conscious in soul, or the world of intension.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Not only in space, but this light and life, this all-feeling being is in our souls.  [Footnote: YaÃ§chÄyamasminnÄtmani tÄjÅmayÅ'mritamayah purushah sarvÄnubhÅ«h.]
next_sentence: Thus to attain our world-consciousness, we have to unite our feeling with this all-pervasive infinite feeling.

question: Doubtless we are directly aware only of the [MASK], and never at any one time of the song as a whole; but do we not all the time know that the complete song is in the soul of the singer?
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: This is like ignoring the consciousness of the singer and saying that only the singing is in progress, that there is no song.
next_sentence: It is because of this insistence on the doing and the becoming that we perceive in the west the intoxication of power.

question: In that actualisation man is ever making himself more and yet more distinct, and seeing himself clearly under newer and newer aspects in the midst of his varied activities, in the state, in [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: The more man acts and makes actual what was latent in him, the nearer does he bring the distant Yet-to-be.
next_sentence: This vision makes for freedom.

question: It is ever in need of external [MASK]; not only to feed its inner consciousness but to apply itself in action, not only to receive but also to give.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: It cannot live on its own internal feelings and imaginings.
next_sentence: The real truth is, we cannot live if we divide him who is truth itself into two parts.

question: If we have an aim and yet can never [MASK] it, then it is no aim at all.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Our existence is meaningless if we never can expect to realise the highest perfection that there is.
next_sentence: But can it then be said that there is no difference between Brahma and our individual soul?

question: His desires are many, and madly they run after the [MASK] objects of the world, for therein they have their life and fulfilment.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: This is the ultimate end of man, to find the One which is in him; which is his truth, which is his soul; the key with which he opens the gate of the spiritual life, the heavenly kingdom.
next_sentence: But that which is one in him is ever seeking for unity--unity in knowledge, unity in love, unity in purposes of will; its highest joy is when it reaches the infinite one within its eternal unity.

question: In the beginning of our apprehension these sharp lines of contrast are helpful to us, but as our comprehension becomes clearer they gradually fade [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: But as it is proceeding farther and farther the line of demarcation between the animate and inanimate is growing more and more dim.
next_sentence: The Upanishads have said that all things are created and sustained by an infinite joy.

question: That it is so has been proved by those who have realised the [MASK] significance of self, and have accepted its responsibilities with eagerness and undergone sacrifices without flinching.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: But if there is a corresponding gain, if it does not end in a void but in a fullness, then it is clear that its negative qualities, its very sufferings and sacrifices, make it all the more precious.
next_sentence: With the foregoing introduction it will be easy for me to answer the question once asked by one of my audience as to whether the annihilation of self has not been held by India as the supreme goal of humanity?

question: In our pleasures we are confined to ourselves, in the good we are freed and we [MASK] to all.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: ], the good which is the daily bread of our souls.
next_sentence: As the child in its mother's womb gets its sustenance through the union of its life with the larger life of its mother, so our soul is nourished only through the good which is the recognition of its inner kinship, the channel of its communication with the infinite by which it is surrounded and fed.

question: It has to be experienced, and this experience is [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: That we cannot absolutely possess the infinite being is not a mere intellectual proposition.
next_sentence: The bird, while taking its flight in the sky, experiences at every beat of its wings that the sky is boundless, that its wings can never carry it beyond.

question: His aim was not to acquire but to realise, to enlarge his consciousness by growing with and growing into his [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Having been in constant contact with the living growth of nature, his mind was free from the desire to extend his dominion by erecting boundary walls around his acquisitions.
next_sentence: He felt that truth is all-comprehensive, that there is no such thing as absolute isolation in existence, and the only way of attaining truth is through the interpenetration of our being into all objects.

question: It [MASK] like a net; we gaze at the big holes and shiver in imagination.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: It is like looking at a piece of cloth through a microscope.
next_sentence: But the truth is, death is not the ultimate reality.

question: The men who are cursed with the gift of the literal mind are the unfortunate [MASK] who are always busy with their nets and neglect the fishing.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: This is the reason why the teachings of our greatest prophets give rise to endless disputations when we try to understand them by following their words and not be realising them in our own lives.
next_sentence: It is not only in Buddhism and the Indian religions, but in Christianity too, that the ideal of selflessness is preached with all fervour.

question: Our life, like a river, strikes its banks not to find itself closed in by them, but to realise anew every [MASK] that it has its unending opening towards the sea.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: For life is immortal youthfulness, and it hates age that tries to clog its movements--age that belongs not to life in truth, but follows it as the shadow follows the lamp.
next_sentence: It is a poem that strikes its metre at every step not to be silenced by its rigid regulations, but to give expression every moment to the inner freedom of its harmony.

question: Could we collect the statistics of the immense amount of death and putrefaction happening every [MASK] in this earth, they would appal us.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: We exaggerate its importance by imagining it as a standstill.
next_sentence: But evil is ever moving; with all its incalculable immensity it does not effectually clog the current of our life; and we find that the earth, water, and air remain sweet and pure for living beings.

question: This illusion will not [MASK] thee in thraldom for ever . ''
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: He will draw thee unto him and make thee his own.
next_sentence: If we happen to be awake then, we question him: "How are we to know that thou art come from him indeed?"

question: The [MASK] has not been lost altogether to us, and there is no man living who would willingly be deprived of his right to suffer pain, for that is his right to be a man.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: The most important lesson that man can learn from his life is not that there is pain in this world, but that it depends upon him to turn it into good account, that it is possible for him to transmute it into joy.
next_sentence: One day the wife of a poor labourer complained bitterly to me that her eldest boy was going to be sent away to a rich relative's house for part of the year.

question: As with [MASK], so with this universe.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: For that by which alone man is true can only be nourished by love and justice.
next_sentence: When we look at the world through the veil of our desires we make it small and narrow, and fail to perceive its full truth.

question: Man in his rÃ´le of a creator is ever [MASK] forms, and they come out of his abounding joy.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: The joy of the singer is expressed in the form of a song, that of the poet in the form of a poem.
next_sentence: This joy, whose other name is love, must by its very nature have duality for its realisation.

question: By the process of knowledge we can never [MASK] the infinite being.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: There is a remarkable saying in the Upanishads: I think not that I know him well, or that I know him, or even that I know him not. [Footnote: NÄham manye suvedeti no na vedeti vedacha.]
next_sentence: But if he is altogether beyond our reach, then he is absolutely nothing to us.

question: The very mountains are cleft asunder and give way before the march of its banners waving triumphantly in the heavens; as the [MASK] before the rising sun, the tangled obscurities of material things vanish at its irresistible approach.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: O thou distraught wanderer, thou Sannyasin, drunk in the wine of self-intoxication, dost thou not already hear the progress of the human soul along the highway traversing the wide fields of humanity--the thunder of its progress in the car of its achievements, which is destined to overpass the bounds that prevent its expansion into the universe?
next_sentence: Pain, disease, and disorder are at every step receding before its onset; the obstructions of ignorance are being thrust aside; the darkness of blindness is being pierced through; and behold, the promised land of wealth and health, of poetry and art, of knowledge and righteousness is gradually being revealed to view.

question: All this would be absolutely unmeaning and [MASK] if all along he did not feel that deepest joy of the soul within him, which tries its divine strength by suffering and proves its exhaustless riches by renunciation.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Man has gone through and is still undergoing martyrdoms in various ways, and his institutions are the altars he has built whereto he brings his daily sacrifices, marvellous in kind and stupendous in quantity.
next_sentence: Yes, they are coming, the pilgrims, one and all--coming to their true inheritance of the world; they are ever broadening their consciousness, ever seeking a higher and higher unity, ever approaching nearer to the one central Truth which is all-comprehensive.

question: It is [MASK] which is monistic, it has no life in it.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: We know that the life of a soul, which is finite in its expression and infinite in its principle, must go through the portals of death in its journey to realise the infinite.
next_sentence: But life is dualistic; it has an appearance as well as truth; and death is that appearance, that mÄyÄ, which is an inseparable companion to life.

question: It may be [MASK] that the infinite is beyond our attainment, so it is for us as if it were naught.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: In all our actions let us feel that impetus of the infinite energy and be glad.
next_sentence: Yes, if the word attainment implies any idea of possession, then it must be admitted that the infinite is unattainable.

question: We want our own pleasure and [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Society is an organism, of which we as parts have our individual wishes.
next_sentence: We want to pay less and gain more than anybody else.

question: When man cuts down the pestilential jungle and makes unto himself a [MASK], the beauty that he thus sets free from within its enclosure of ugliness is the beauty of his own soul: without giving it this freedom outside, he cannot make it free within.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: It wants to see itself, to realise itself.
next_sentence: When he implants law and order in the midst of the waywardness of society, the good which he sets free from the obstruction of the bad is the goodness of his own soul: without being thus made free outside it cannot find freedom within.

question: Similarly, when we talk about the relative values of freedom and non-freedom, it becomes a mere play of [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: And in him who is love the finite and the infinite are made one.
next_sentence: It is not that we desire freedom alone, we want thraldom as well.

question: Even the most evilly-disposed [MASK] has to recognise this when it seeks the power to do evil; for it cannot ignore truth and yet be strong.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: It is a truth that man is not a detached being, that he has a universal aspect; and when he recognises this he becomes great.
next_sentence: So in order to claim the aid of truth, selfishness has to be unselfish to some extent.

question: It is like convicting a [MASK] of suicide, while all the time he stands before you in the flesh.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: If existence were an evil, it would wait for no philosopher to prove it.
next_sentence: Existence itself is here to prove that it cannot be an evil.

question: With [MASK] and service, with a regulation of life, she cultivated her consciousness in such a way that everything had a spiritual meaning to her.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: The fundamental unity of creation was not simply a philosophical speculation for India; it was her life-object to realise this great harmony in feeling and in action.
next_sentence: The earth, water and light, fruits and flowers, to her were not merely physical phenomena to be turned to use and then left aside.

question: Our eyes naturally see an [MASK] as a whole, not by breaking it up into parts, but by bringing all the parts together into a unity with ourselves.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: The vision of the Supreme One in our own soul is a direct and immediate intuition, not based on any ratiocination or demonstration at all.
next_sentence: So with the intuition of our Soul-consciousness, which naturally and totally realises its unity in the Supreme One.

question: And that is the reason why it overspreads the sky like a thought taking shape in a poem, and never has to break into pieces with the burden of its own [MASK] weight.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Every moment it comes from the heart of the master, it is breathed in his breath.
next_sentence: Hence the surprise of endless variations, the advent of the unaccountable, the ceaseless procession of individuals, each of whom is without a parallel in creation.

question: Man can destroy and plunder, earn and accumulate, [MASK] and discover, but he is great because his soul comprehends all.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: / ]  Thus the state of realising our relationship with all, of entering into everything through union with God, was considered in India to be the ultimate end and fulfilment of humanity.
next_sentence: It is dire destruction for him when he envelopes his soul in a dead shell of callous habits, and when a blind fury of works whirls round him like an eddying dust storm, shutting out the horizon.

question: \"]; they are not [MASK] upon him from outside.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: God's manifestation is in his work of creation and it is said in the Upanishad, Knowledge, power, and action are of his nature [Footnote: "SvÄbhÄvikÄ« jnÄna bala kriyÄcha.
next_sentence: Therefore his work is his freedom, and in his creation he realises himself.

question: In the [MASK] the sky is limited; it may be quite enough for all the purposes of the bird's life, only it is not more than is necessary.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Therein lies its joy.
next_sentence: The bird cannot rejoice within the limits of the necessary.

question: Separateness is the finitude where it finds its barriers to come back again and again to its [MASK] source.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: For in its career of separateness it cannot go on for ever.
next_sentence: Our self has ceaselessly to cast off its age, repeatedly shed its limits in oblivion and death, in order to realise its immortal youth.

question: When the heat and motion of blind [MASK] and passions distract it on all sides, we can neither give nor receive anything truly.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: So with our soul.
next_sentence: But when we find our centre in our soul by the power of self-restraint, by the force that harmonises all warring elements and unifies those that are apart, then all our isolated impressions reduce themselves to wisdom, and all our momentary impulses of heart find their completion in love; then all the petty details of our life reveal an infinite purpose, and all our thoughts and deeds unite themselves inseparably in an internal harmony.

question: Love must be one and two at the same [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Only in love are unity and duality not at variance.
next_sentence: Only love is motion and rest in one.

question: There is a [MASK] of harmony between our two eyes, which makes them act in unison.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: These forces, like the left and the right hands of the creator, are acting in absolute harmony, yet acting from opposite directions.
next_sentence: Likewise there is an unbreakable continuity of relation in the physical world between heat and cold, light and darkness, motion and rest, as between the bass and treble notes of a piano.

question: It is the extinction of the lamp in the morning [MASK]; not the abolition of the sun.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Then comes our teacher's call to die to this death; not a call to annihilation but to eternal life.
next_sentence: It is really asking us consciously to give effect to the innermost wish that we have in the depths of our nature.

question: In all our deeper [MASK] getting and non-getting run ever parallel.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: In all our intellectual pleasures the margin is broader, the limit is far off.
next_sentence: In one of our Vaishnava lyrics the lover says to his beloved: "I feel as if I have gazed upon the beauty of thy face from my birth, yet my eyes are hungry still: as if I have kept thee pressed to my heart for millions of years, yet my heart is not satisfied."

question: To a certain [MASK] we can set our life against the law of truth which is in us and which is in all, and likewise we can give rise to ugliness by going counter to the eternal law of harmony which is everywhere.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: In the same manner there is ugliness in the distorted expression of beauty in our life and in our art which comes from our imperfect realisation of Truth.
next_sentence: Through our sense of truth we realise law in creation, and through our sense of beauty we realise harmony in the universe.

question: The soul of man is ever freeing itself from its own folds by its activity; had it been otherwise it could not have [MASK] any voluntary work.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Likewise it is because the soul cannot find freedom within itself that it wants external action.
next_sentence: The more man acts and makes actual what was latent in him, the nearer does he bring the distant Yet-to-be.

question: When man's consciousness is restricted only to the immediate vicinity of his human self, the deeper roots of his nature do not find their permanent soil, his spirit is ever on the brink of [MASK], and in the place of healthful strength he substitutes rounds of stimulation.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Then it is that in our self-expression we try to startle and not to attract; in art we strive for originality and lose sight of truth which is old and yet ever new; in literature we miss the complete view of man which is simple and yet great, but he appears as a psychological problem or the embodiment of a passion that is intense because abnormal and because exhibited in the glare of a fiercely emphatic light which is artificial.
next_sentence: Then it is that man misses his inner perspective and measures his greatness by its bulk and not by its vital link with the infinite, judges his activity by its movement and not by the repose of perfection--the repose which is in the starry heavens, in the ever-flowing rhythmic dance of creation.

question: It would be utterly [MASK] for us to live in a world immeasurably less than ourselves in the quality of soul, just as it would be repulsive and degrading to be surrounded and served by a host of slaves, day and night, from birth to the moment of death.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: No, we are not burdened with some monstrous superiority, unmeaning in its singular abruptness.
next_sentence: On the contrary, this world is our compeer, nay, we are one with it.

question: They [MASK] before us opportunities for surrendering our all.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Buddha and Jesus, and all our great prophets, represent such great ideas.
next_sentence: When they bring forth their divine alms-bowl we feel we cannot help giving, and we find that in giving is our truest joy and liberation, for it is uniting ourselves to that extent with the infinite.

question: In the same form, sound, colour, and taste two contrary notes are heard, one of necessity and the other of [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: It indeed seems to be wonderful that nature has these two aspects at one and the same time, and so antithetical--one being of thraldom and the other of freedom.
next_sentence: Outwardly nature is busy and restless, inwardly she is all silence and peace.

question: If there were [MASK] else to take its place more positively perfect and satisfying, then such admonition would be absolutely unmeaning.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: This is the reason why Buddha admonished us to free ourselves from the confinement of the life of the self.
next_sentence: No man can seriously consider the advice, much less have any enthusiasm for it, of surrendering everything one has for gaining nothing whatever.

question: And then when the work is finished the [MASK] is gone, the windowed picture stands alone, the incessant touches of love of the creative hand are withdrawn.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: The first touch of his brush is very far from the complete idea.
next_sentence: But the singer has everything within him.

question: But [MASK] never has to depend upon any obvious meaning; it expresses what no words can ever express.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: As the material of expression even words are barriers, for their meaning has to be constructed by thought.
next_sentence: What is more, music and the musician are inseparable.

question: For [MASK] is the divine food of the soul; nothing but this can fill him, can make him live the life of the infinite, can help him in his growth towards the eternal.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Hence it is said, "Blessed are they which do hunger and thirst after righteousness: for they shall be filled."
next_sentence: We bow to thee from whom come the enjoyments of our life.  [Footnote: Namah sambhavÄya.]

question: In the sphere of nature the flower carries with it a certificate which recommends it as having immense capacity for doing useful work, but it brings an altogether different [MASK] of introduction when it knocks at the door of our hearts.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: But our heart replies that we are not in the least mistaken.
next_sentence: Beauty becomes its only qualification.

question: The tyrant who must have slaves [MASK] upon them as instruments of his purpose.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: The reason of it is that the will, which is love's will and therefore free, can have its joy only in a union with another free will.
next_sentence: It is the consciousness of his own necessity which makes him crush the will out of them, to make his self-interest absolutely secure.

question: Every time we lose some of our badges of absolute distinction by which we conferred upon our humanity the right to [MASK] itself apart from its surroundings, it gives us a shock of humiliation.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Yet the more his knowledge progresses, the more it becomes difficult for man to establish this separateness, and all the imaginary boundaries he had set up around himself vanish one after another.
next_sentence: But we have to submit to this.

question: Our relation to food is only in feeding, our [MASK] to a house is only in habitation.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: We can have a thing only to the extent of our requirements, just as a vessel can contain water only to the extent of its emptiness.
next_sentence: We call it a benefit when a thing is fitted only to some particular want of ours.

question: This does not lead us to power, as knowledge does, but it gives us [MASK], which is the product of the union of kindred things.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: This is not mere knowledge, as science is, but it is a preception of the soul by the soul.
next_sentence: The man whose acquaintance with the world does not lead him deeper than science leads him, will never understand what it is that the man with the spiritual vision finds in these natural phenomena.

question: It has [MASK] quite a commonplace fact, yet it is wonderful to think upon, that the joys and sorrows of our loved ones are joys and sorrows to us--nay they are more.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: ParamÄtmÄ, the supreme soul, is in me, as well as in my son, and my joy in my son is the realisation of this truth.
next_sentence: Why so?

question: There was a time when we prayed for special concessions, we expected that the laws of nature should be [MASK] in abeyance for our own convenience.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Only by discovering the law and following it, do we become great, do we realise the universal; while, so long as our individual desires are at conflict with the universal law, we suffer pain and are futile.
next_sentence: But now we know better.

question: For they only indicate our own [MASK] self.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: All our egoistic impulses, our selfish desires, obscure our true vision of the soul.
next_sentence: When we are conscious of our soul, we perceive the inner being that transcends our ego and has its deeper affinity with the All.

question: Thus it is only avidyÄ which makes the self our fetter by making us [MASK] that it is an end in itself, and by preventing our seeing that it contains the idea that transcends its limits.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: No, when the perfect knowledge comes, every word remains in its place, only they do not bind us to themselves, but let us pass through them and lead us to the idea which is emancipation.
next_sentence: That is why the wise man comes and says, "Set yourselves free from the avidyÄ; know your true soul and be saved from the grasp of the self which imprisons you."

question: It must be the aim of the [MASK] of our life.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: The Upanishads say: Be lost altogether in Brahma like an arrow that has completely penetrated its target.  Thus to be conscious of being absolutely enveloped by Brahma is not an act of mere concentration of mind.
next_sentence: In all our thoughts and deeds we must be conscious of the infinite.

question: Dharma is the [MASK] nature, the essence, the implicit truth, of all things.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: The Sanskrit word dharma which is usually translated into English as religion has a deeper meaning in our language.
next_sentence: Dharma is the ultimate purpose that is working in our self.

question: The world still appears to us as a machine, to be mastered where it is useful, to be guarded against where it is dangerous, and never to be known in its full fellowship with us, alike in its physical nature and in its spiritual life and [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: While yet we have not attained the internal harmony, and the wholeness of our being, our life remains a life of habits.
next_sentence: III   THE PROBLEM OF EVIL   The question why there is evil in existence is the same as why there is imperfection, or, in other words, why there is creation at all.

question: No, when the perfect knowledge comes, every word remains in its place, only they do not bind us to themselves, but let us [MASK] through them and lead us to the idea which is emancipation.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: But it would be foolish to say that our ignorance of the language can be dispelled only by the destruction of the words.
next_sentence: Thus it is only avidyÄ which makes the self our fetter by making us think that it is an end in itself, and by preventing our seeing that it contains the idea that transcends its limits.

question: When we take food and satisfy our [MASK] it is a complete act of possession.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: They, like the dead satellite of the earth, have but little atmosphere around them.
next_sentence: So long as the hunger is not satisfied it is a pleasure to eat.

question: Our pursuit of truth in the [MASK] of nature therefore is through analysis and the gradual methods of science, but our apprehension of truth in our soul is immediate and through direct intuition.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: He is Vishvakarma; that is, in a multiplicity of forms and forces lies his outward manifestation in nature; but his inner manifestation in our soul is that which exists in unity.
next_sentence: We cannot attain the supreme soul by successive additions of knowledge acquired bit by bit even through all eternity, because he is one, he is not made up of parts; we can only know him as heart of our hearts and soul of our soul; we can only know him in the love and joy we feel when we give up our self and stand before him face to face.

question: The freed soul delights in accepting bonds, and does not seek to evade any of them, for in each does it feel the manifestation of an infinite energy whose [MASK] is in creation.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Not that the bonds of law have ceased to exist for them--but that the bonds have become to them as the form of freedom incarnate.
next_sentence: As a matter of fact, where there are no bonds, where there is the madness of license, the soul ceases to be free.

question: It is like dividing the [MASK] and the blossom into two separate categories, and putting their grace to the credit of two different and antithetical principles.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: According to it, everything that is low in the scale of beings is merely nature, and whatever has the stamp of perfection on it, intellectual or moral, is human-nature.
next_sentence: But the Indian mind never has any hesitation in acknowledging its kinship with nature, its unbroken relation with all.

question: Give us [MASK] to love, to love fully, our life in its joys and sorrows, in its gains and losses, in its rise and fall.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: at the vision of thee as joy let our souls flame up to thee as the fire, flow on to thee as the river, permeate thy being as the fragrance of the flower.
next_sentence: Let us have strength enough fully to see and hear thy universe, and to work with full vigour therein.

question: It enlarges our scope of consciousness, no doubt, yet it sets a [MASK] to its freest expansion.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: It very often happens that our love for our children, our friends, or other loved ones, debars us from the further realisation of our soul.
next_sentence: Nevertheless, it is the first step, and all the wonder lies in this first step itself.

question: Hunger compels us to [MASK] its behests, but hunger is not the last word for a man.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: It tells us everywhere that the display of power is not the ultimate meaning of creation; wherever there is a bit of colour, a note of song, a grace of form, there comes the call for our love.
next_sentence: There have been men who have deliberately defied its commands to show that the human soul is not to be led by the pressure of wants and threat of pain.

question: Day after day we [MASK] toiling on, but on towards what, we had not the least notion.
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: I remember in our childhood we had a teacher who used to make us learn by heart the whole book of Sanskrit grammer, which is written in symbols, without explaining their meaning to us.
next_sentence: So, as regards our lessons, we were in the position of the pessimist who only counts the breathless activities of the world, but cannot see the infinite repose of the perfection whence these activities are gaining their equilibrium every moment in absolute fitness and harmony.

question: But when we are possessed by love, its force acts in the opposite [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: They seem to belong to our very nature, to stick to us as a second skin, and we bleed as we detach them.
next_sentence: The things that closely adhered to us lose their adhesion and weight, and we find that they are not of us.

question: The water does not merely cleanse his limbs, but it purifies his heart; for it touches his [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: The man whose acquaintance with the world does not lead him deeper than science leads him, will never understand what it is that the man with the spiritual vision finds in these natural phenomena.
next_sentence: The earth does not merely hold his body, but it gladdens his mind; for its contact is more than a physical contact--it is a living presence.

question: His existence is miserable and sordid till he finds some great idea which can truly claim his all, which can release him from all attachment to his [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: They make it easier for him to part with all that he has, not expecting his life.
next_sentence: Buddha and Jesus, and all our great prophets, represent such great ideas.

question: They would always obstinately be doing and never be done--they would not allow to death its natural place in the scheme of things--they know not the beauty of [MASK].
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: These men seem to have determined to despoil and grasp everything by force.
next_sentence: In our country the danger comes from the opposite side.

question: Who so steeped in untruth as to dare to call all this untrue--this great world of men, this civilisation of expanding [MASK], this eternal effort of man, through depths of sorrow, through heights of gladness, through innumerable impediments within and without, to win victory for his powers?
source_info: Sadhana : the realisation of life by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Sadhana : the realisation of life
prev_sentence: Who so foolish as to run away from the gladsome throng and seek him in the listlessness of inaction?
next_sentence: He who can think of this immensity of achievement as an immense fraud, can he truly believe in God who is the truth?

question: Joy is the outcome of detachment from self and lives in freedom of [MASK].
source_info: Creative Unity by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Creative Unity
prev_sentence: It is necessary to note, however, that joy is not pleasure, and beauty not mere prettiness.
next_sentence: Beauty is that profound expression of reality which satisfies our hearts without any other allurements but its own ultimate value.

question: The spirit of national selfishness is that brain disease of a people which shows itself in red eyes and [MASK] fists, in violence of talk and movements, all the while shattering its natural restorative powers.
source_info: Creative Unity by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Creative Unity
prev_sentence: For it is the brain that is constantly directing the siege against all disease forces.
next_sentence: But the power of self-sacrifice, together with the moral faculty of sympathy and co-operation, is the guiding spirit of social vitality.

question: Opening your [MASK] to that which is seen only, is to lose it.
source_info: Creative Unity by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Creative Unity
prev_sentence: The BaÃ¼l poet expressly says that if we try to approach God through the senses we miss him:      Bring him not into your house as the guest of your eyes;         but let him come at your heart's invitation.
next_sentence: Yet, being a poet, he also knows that the objects of sense can reveal their spiritual meaning only when they are not seen through mere physical eyes:      Eyes can see only dust and earth,     But feel it with your heart, it is pure joy.

question: Like [MASK], they spread their roots in the soil and their branches in the sky, without consulting any architect for their plans.
source_info: Creative Unity by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Creative Unity
prev_sentence: Our moral ideals do not work with chisels and hammers.
next_sentence: WOMAN AND HOME   Creative expressions attain their perfect form through emotions modulated.

question: This [MASK] to a people who live by the sea, and ride on it as on a wild, champing horse, catching it by its mane and making it render service from shore to shore.
source_info: Creative Unity by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Creative Unity
prev_sentence: This fight he still maintains; it is the fight against disease and poverty, tyranny of matter and of man.
next_sentence: They find delight in turning by force the antagonism of circumstances into obedience.

question: Such is the [MASK] of human nature.
source_info: Creative Unity by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Creative Unity
prev_sentence: At last the very authorities who are responsible for this are blaming their victims.
next_sentence: It bears its worst grudge against those it has injured.

question: Most patriotic poems have the same [MASK].
source_info: Creative Unity by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Creative Unity
prev_sentence: For in them the deliberate subject, assuming the first importance, benumbs or kills the poem.
next_sentence: They are like hill streams born of sudden showers, which are more proud of their rocky beds than of their water currents; in them the athletic and arrogant subject takes it for granted that the poem is there to give it occasion to display its powers.

question: It is the unequal freedom in their mutual [MASK] which has made the weight of life's tragedies so painfully heavy for woman to bear.
source_info: Creative Unity by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Creative Unity
prev_sentence: This liberty exacts payment when it offers its boon, because to give or to withhold the gift is within its power.
next_sentence: Some mitigation of her disadvantage has been effected by her rendering herself and her home a luxury to man.

question: It unconsciously generates in [MASK]'s minds an attitude of defiance against moral law.
source_info: Creative Unity by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: Creative Unity
prev_sentence: But when this idea of the Nation, which has met with universal acceptance in the present day, tries to pass off the cult of collective selfishness as a moral duty, simply because that selfishness is gigantic in stature, it not only commits depredation, but attacks the very vitals of humanity.
next_sentence: For men are taught by repeated devices the lesson that the Nation is greater than the people, while yet it scatters to the winds the moral law that the people have held sacred.

question: His wide appreciation of art and talent kept him [MASK] radiant with enthusiasm.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: Whether in his broad south verandah, or on the lawn by the fountain, or at the tank-edge on the fishing platform, he presided over self-invited gatherings, like hospitality incarnate.
next_sentence: New ideas of festivity or frolic, theatricals or other entertainments, found in him a ready patron, and with his help would flourish and find fruition.

question: It did not prove possible to get the big [MASK] to do anything.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: Pandit Vidyasagar's prophecy was fulfilled.
next_sentence: And the academy withered away shortly after sprouting.

question: One can [MASK] how such a tutor can get pupils, for these poor creatures do not often get the chance of making a choice.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: Except his mild little wife there was not a thing with any pretensions to attractiveness about this household.
next_sentence: But it is painful to think of the conditions under which such men get wives.

question: If the divergence is too wide, or the unison too close, there is, it seems to me, no room for [MASK].
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: As in all creation, so in poetry, there is the opposition of forces.
next_sentence: Where the pain of discord strives to attain and express its resolution into harmony, there does poetry break forth into music, as breath through a flute.

question: The topmost room of the house was in a round tower with windows [MASK] to every side.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: Some far-away long-forgotten revelry seemed to be expressing itself in silent words of light; the love thrills of the swinging couple making alive with their eternal story the woodlands of the river bank.
next_sentence: This I used as my room for writing poetry.

question: First of all it was a room [MASK] closed, and then there was the stolen entry, this gave it a deep flavour of mystery; further the broad empty expanse of terrace to the south, glowing in the rays of the sun would set me day-dreaming.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: I would pass my hands through the venetian shutters, and thus opening the latch get the door open, and spend the afternoon lying motionless on his sofa at the south end.
next_sentence: There was yet another attraction.

question: He was [MASK] as to the sort of life one led where he was.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: At one of the sittings the pencil scrawled out the name of Kailash.
next_sentence: Not a bit of it, was the reply.

question: My father, seated amidst the throng of worshippers, would sometimes add his [MASK] to the hymn of praise, and finding a stranger joining in their devotions they would wax enthusiastically cordial, and we would return loaded with the sanctified offerings of sugar crystals and other sweets.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: There the sacred chanting resounds continually.
next_sentence: One day my father invited one of the chanting choir to our place and got him to sing us some of their sacred songs.

question: His ecstatic declamation of the sonorous [MASK] was enough for me.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: I could not, nor had I the need to, understand a word of the Sanskrit.
next_sentence: Then, again, before I could properly understand English, a profusely illustrated edition of "The Old Curiosity Shop" fell into my hands.

question: He had been a village [MASK] before.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: His name was Iswar.
next_sentence: He was a prim, proper and sedately dignified personage.

question: In infancy the loving care of woman is to be had without the asking, and, being as much a necessity as light and air, is as simply accepted without any conscious [MASK]; rather does the growing child often display an eagerness to free itself from the encircling web of woman's solicitude.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: And she who was then the youngest bride of our house lavished on me a wealth of affection and regard.
next_sentence: But the unfortunate creature who is deprived of this in its proper season is beggared indeed.

question: In the midday glare of modern life even our hours of mental siesta have been narrowed down to the lowest limit, and hydra-headed unrest has [MASK] every department of life.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: Our little river-side nests, clustering under their surrounding greenery, have been replaced by mills which now, dragon-like, everywhere rear their hissing heads, belching forth black smoke.
next_sentence: Maybe, this is for the better, but I, for one, cannot account it wholly to the good.

question: His people at home [MASK] him a crank.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: Some days in the course of our lessons he would suddenly be at a loss for some word and look vacant and ashamed.
next_sentence: He had become possessed of a theory.

question: One of these will [MASK] to be dilated upon.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: They were all older than we.
next_sentence: His specialty was the art of Magic, so much so that he had actually written and published a little booklet on it, the front page of which bore his name with the title of Professor.

question: When stagnation [MASK] in then comes the danger.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: I now clearly see that the mistake is to judge boys by the standard of grown-ups, to forget that a child is quick and mobile like a running stream; and that, in the case of such, any touch of imperfection need cause no great alarm, for the speed of the flow is itself the best corrective.
next_sentence: So it is for the teacher, more than the pupil, to beware of wrongdoing.

question: Very few have this [MASK] of conversation, and fewer still the art of translating it into writing.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: Those who have read his prose writing must have noticed how gaily and airily it flows on like the sprightliest of conversation.
next_sentence: This was the time when Pandit Sashadhar rose into prominence.

question: Memory is the brush which can best [MASK] on the true poetic colour.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: Just as it does not do to have the writer entirely removed from the feeling to which he is giving expression, so also it does not conduce to the truest poetry to have him too close to it.
next_sentence: Nearness has too much of the compelling about it and the imagination is not sufficiently free unless it can get away from its influence.

question: When motion has been born, while yet the [MASK] of forces has not matured, then is there blind chaos indeed.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: What was my own was the restlessness, the seething tension within me.
next_sentence: My sister-in-law[35] was a great lover of literature.

question: The [MASK] here were annoying but not disgusting--which was a great comfort.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: What we were taught there we never understood, nor did we make any attempt to learn, nor did it seem to make any difference to anybody that we did not.
next_sentence: They wrote ASS on their palms and slapped it on to our backs with a cordial "hello!"

question: Of the inner person, behind the [MASK] current of thoughts, feelings and events, but little is known or recked; but for all that, he cannot be got rid of as a factor in life's progress.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: There is a duality in man.
next_sentence: When the outward life fails to harmonise with the inner, the dweller within is hurt, and his pain manifests itself in the outer consciousness in a manner to which it is difficult to give a name, or even to describe, and of which the cry is more akin to an inarticulate wail than words with more precise meaning.

question: The poetry which attempts its expression cannot be called baseless--at [MASK] it may be worthless; but it is not necessarily even that.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: There is a period in man's life when his feelings are the pathos of the inexpressible, the anguish of vagueness.
next_sentence: The sin is not in the thing expressed, but in the failure to express it.

question: The weight of stone of which the floor was relieved settled on our minds when we realised the gulf between our fancies and the will of our [MASK].
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: The knowledge that the schoolroom floor was not a proper foundation for the erection of a mountain was imparted so rudely, and with such suddenness, that it gave us a considerable shock.
next_sentence: How intimately did the life of the world throb for us in those days!

question: If by any chance my eldest brother happened to be passing that way, and caught a glimpse of our sleep-tormented [MASK], we would get let off for the rest of the evening.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: Sprinkling water into our eyes, or taking a run round the verandahs, were palliatives which had no lasting effect.
next_sentence: It did not take our drowsiness another moment to get completely cured.

question: The fact is my self had not yet been moulded and nourished into a strong and definite personality and so my life drifted along as light and [MASK] as an autumn cloud.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: Sometimes a whole day would be spent in the same way.
next_sentence: (40) Bankim Chandra   This was the time when my acquaintance with Bankim Babu began.

question: The light of my country, the [MASK] of my country, had been silently calling me.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: I was delighted at the prospect.
next_sentence: When I said good bye Mrs. Scott took me by the hand and wept.

question: And if the fuel of error was [MASK] for feeding the flame of enthusiasm then while that which was fit to be reduced to ashes will have become ash, the good work done by the flame will not have been in vain in my life.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: It was a period to which, if error was natural, so was the boyish faculty of hoping, believing and rejoicing.
next_sentence: PART V     (24) Ahmedabad   When the Bharati entered upon its second year, my second brother proposed to take me to England; and when my father gave his consent, this further unasked favour of providence came on me as a surprise.

question: We knew that to mention the cheapest would be accounted best, so sometimes we ordered a light [MASK] of puffed rice, and at others an indigestible one of boiled gram or roasted groundnuts.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: He would ask us every morning what we should like to have.
next_sentence: It was evident that Iswar was not as painstakingly punctilious in regard to our diet as with the shastric proprieties.

question: The power of organising a large number of men into a corporate group [MASK] on a special kind of genius.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: In any other country, where large political, social or commercial groups are being formed, such would as naturally become national leaders.
next_sentence: Such genius in our country runs to waste, a waste, as pitiful, it seems to me, as that of pulling down a star from the firmament for use as a lucifer match.

question: On moonlight nights pacing round and round the extensive [MASK] overlooking the river was one of my caprices.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: Sometimes a wasp or two would drop off the nest on to my bed, and if perchance I happened to roll on one, the meeting was unpleasing to the wasp and keenly discomforting to me.
next_sentence: It was while so doing that I first composed my own tunes for my songs.

question: Emptiness is a thing man cannot bring himself to believe in; that which is not, is untrue; that which is [MASK], is not.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: I would ever and anon return to take my stand there and gaze upon it, wondering what there was left in place of what had gone.
next_sentence: So our efforts to find something, where we see nothing, are unceasing.

question: Of what words kallokee is the transformation still [MASK] me.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: I can recall only one line:  Kallokee pullokee singill mellaling mellaling mellaling.  After much thought I have been able to guess at the original of a part of it.
next_sentence: The rest I think was:  ... full of glee, singing merrily, merrily, merrily!  As my memories of the Normal School emerge from haziness and become clearer they are not the least sweet in any particular.

question: But it will [MASK] live in my memory.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: Some of the members of the Doctor's family have departed to the other world, others are scattered in places unknown to me.
