question: It spread an [MASK] of vague beauty over my mind.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: I can well remember this line:      The night that was passed in the lonely forest cottage.
next_sentence: That one Sanskrit word, Nibhrita-nikunja-griham, meaning "the lonely forest cottage" was quite enough for me.

question: The result was that we had to take stern measures of self-defence ,--such an insistent army of [MASK] invaded us.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: The man went away probably more than satisfied with the reward he received.
next_sentence: When they found our house impregnable, the musicians began to waylay us in the streets.

question: The pleasure of thus separately marking off each picture was much the same as that of painting it, both being the outcome of the [MASK] to see with the mind what the eye sees, and with the eye what the mind imagines.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: Each little separate picture I ringed round with the light of my imagination and the joy of my heart; every one of them, moreover, being variously coloured by a pathos of its own.
next_sentence: Had I been a painter with the brush I would doubtless have tried to keep a permanent record of the visions and creations of that period when my mind was so alertly responsive.

question: To be called upon to submit to the customs and fashions of the day, as if they were something soberly and [MASK] real, made me want to laugh.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: At this time I was attacked with a recrudescence of eccentricity in thought and behaviour.

question: In all her actions her reverence for her [MASK] was the one thing that stood out.

title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: She could not bear the idea of Satan having anything to do, even for a moment, with her husband's head-gear.
next_sentence: The memory of her sweet self-abnegation makes it clear to me that the ultimate perfection of all womanly love is to be found in reverence; that where no extraneous cause has hampered its true development woman's love naturally grows into worship.

source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: While in other parts of the world there is no end to the movement and clamour of the revelry of free life, we, like the beggar maid, stand outside and longingly look on.
next_sentence: Only in a country where the spirit of separation reigns supreme, and innumerable petty barriers divide one from another, need this longing to realise the larger life of the world in one's own remain unsatisfied.

title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: We had been through Akshay Datta's book on Popular Physics, and had also finished the epic of Meghnadvadha.

source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: I consoled myself with the thought that I might never get another such opportunity of concentrating my whole attention on such a subject.

question: Then do its nebulous emanations shrink upon themselves, get heated, and [MASK] in their turn.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: Gradually it comes to      understand what it really wants and what it does not.
next_sentence: To begin by wanting the whole world is to get nothing.

question: When love [MASK] the gulf between the two, and the hermit and the householder met, the seeming triviality of the finite and the seeming emptiness of the infinite alike disappeared.

title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: In the Nature's Revenge there were shown on the one side the wayfarers and the villagers, content with their home-made triviality and unconscious of anything beyond; and on the other the Sanyasi busy casting away his all, and himself, into the self-evolved infinite of his imagination.
next_sentence: This was to put in a slightly different form the story of my own experience, of the entrancing ray of light which found its way into the depths of the cave into which I had retired away from all touch with the outer world, and made me more fully one with Nature again.

title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: The row of doors leading into the rooms are all closed.

question: There was not a leaf on the row of trees in front which stood staring at the [MASK] with their scraggy snow-covered branches--a sight which chilled my very bones.

title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: It was then the depth of winter.

title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: Its other appendages were so abundant and satisfying that we felt the absence of dead or wounded game to be a trifling circumstance of no account.

question: When the time for reaping arrives no one thinks of these pioneers; but those who have cheerfully staked and lost their all, during life, are not likely, after death, to mind this further loss of being [MASK].

title: My Reminiscences

question: The [MASK] is not in the thing expressed, but in the failure to express it.

title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: The poetry which attempts its expression cannot be called baseless--at worst it may be worthless; but it is not necessarily even that.

question: His whole bearing had the appearance of an effort to keep clear of the imperfections which, through [MASK] avenues, find entrance into earth, water and air, and into the ways of men.

title: My Reminiscences

title: My Reminiscences

source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: "Being a boy," I thought, "I am helpless and read many books because I have to.

question: In the wide wide world there might be found another, his equal in pertinacity, but never in this [MASK] lane of ours.
source_info: My Reminiscences by Tagore, Rabindranath
title: My Reminiscences

question: It was because of this music [MASK] within that nothing then felt trivial to the writer.

title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: When the string of the mind is properly attuned to the universe then at each point the universal song can awaken its sympathetic vibrations.

question: This old man was the friend alike of my [MASK], my elder brothers and ourselves.

title: My Reminiscences

question: My overweening conceit made me stick to my guns and argue the [MASK] with him at length.

title: My Reminiscences
prev_sentence: I did it in my way, but he thought a different explanation would fit better.

title: My Reminiscences

title: My Reminiscences

title: My Reminiscences
